text: Hello guys. Welcome to Vientiane, the capital city of Laos. Yes,
we are in Vientiane today and we are going to visiting a couple
of different things today; we are going to a rehabilitation clinic
where basically they rehabilitate all the victims of unexploded
bombs that go off in Laos. In case you didn't know, Laos was
bombed alot during the Vietnam war. Actually it was the most
bombed country in the world. First, we are here at the 'Arc de
Triomphe'. Yes, if you recognize this, apparently it is a reprica of
the Paris' 'Arc de Triomphe', but this one has more of an Asian
flare to it. So lets climb up that and take a look at Vientiane.
Good timing fountain, good timing.

I just want to tell you a bit about 
 the history and why do we
come and see. Behind me the statue of King Satthathirath
established the capital city of Vientiane in 1563.
Welcome to Laos and welcome to COPE center.We are going

to talk about the war. Even if the 
 war ended a long time ago,
many Lao people, many inoccent children are being injured by
bombs and have been injured by cluster bombs, still over 100
people per year. That's lots of people.
These dots represents bombs.The cluster bomb is dropped, it
opens in air it opens into sub munitions, contained incide, there
680 sub-munitons or shrapnel for 1 bomb. Do you know how
many? 19 different kinds and 260 million of these.
dropped in Laos and right now there are 80 million unexploded
left in the ground. So how come people are still being injured by
these bombs?Because 80% of Laos people are farmers, so
when they go to collect food, and the jungle, and the farms, they
step on the bombs and explode.
So this we are talking about COPE. What does Cope do?
Cope provides prosthetics for people who need it, lost legs.
This one is from here down. We make it pretty complete.
The cost to make this one, just for one person who needs it, is
75 dollars. If they need a new one they can come and get it.
Cope pays for those people that need it, bus ticket,
accomodation even if they have to stay here one month, two
months, cope pays for everthing.
What's up. Hey guys, I just wanted to have a little one-on-one
What's up. Hey guys, I just wanted to have a little one-on-one
conversation with you guys after the Cope centre. I know it was

a lot to take in, a lot of information 
 there. One, the fact that I am
very sick right now. I know you can't really tell. It's not that sick,

really matter how sick I am because at 
 the end of the day, I still

have all my limbs and I am very 
 lucky to be where I am.
75 bucks I just bought somebody a leg today. I know my leg is
